review: I have used the Chromecast for a few days and have been pretty happy with it so far. We have a multi-OS household and a variety of streaming devices including Apple TV and Roku. If you have an Android supported device, the Chromecast is a terrific value. My LG G2 is on the supported list which gives me one benefit that other devices in my household do not posess. I can mirror my screen to Chromecast. This gives me an ease of use and allows a greater variety of content. It's easy to view pictures and videos without the need for special apps. When using a 3rd gen iPad or even the new iPhone 5s, I don't see the mirror feature.Though mirroring is nice, it negates one of the best uses for Chromecast. That's the ability to let Chromecast fetch the content itself. You use an app like netflix on your phone or tablet, choose the content and select cast as opposed to local viewing. That free's up your phone to do other things while you watch. You can leave and let the video play by itself. Though not quite as robust as AppleTV or Roku, if your needs are limited to the supported Chromecast apps, it's a great value and less obtrusive as a device since it just plugs into an HDMI port.The only extra wire you'll need is a power chord which though supplied with the hardware is adds a bit of clutter since it needs to be plugged into a powered usb source. If your TV doesn't have a usb plug for power you can use the supplied wall adapter.

review: Easy to use, plug and play. Makes watching Netflix and YouTube videos on my TV that much easier. The real seller for me though was the free two months of Netflix included when I bought it and the ability to cast any tab I could open in Chrome. It falls a little short on the Chrome casting as I can't reliably get this to work with fulls screen video, but it works great for everything else. The screen saver like photos displayed on your TV when it's not being used are also quite nice.
